articles.description: President Donald Trump has played golf at his course on Scotland’s coast while protesters around the country took to the streets to decry his visit and accuse United Kingdom leaders of pandering to the American. Trump and his son Eric played on Saturday near Turnberry, a historic course that the Trump family’s company took over in 2008. Meanwhile, hundreds of protesters gathered in front of the U.S. Consulate about 100 miles away in Edinburgh, Scotland’s capital. Protests are planned in other cities. While in Scotland, Trump is set to talk trade with British Prime Minister Keir Starmer and Ursula von der Leyen, the European Commission president.
articles.title: Trump plays golf in Scotland as protesters take to the streets

articles.description: A key House committee is looking into the investigation of the late Jeffrey Epstein for sex trafficking crimes. It is working to subpoena President Donald Trump’s Department of Justice for files in the case as well as hold a deposition of Epstein’s former girlfriend, Ghislaine Maxwell. The Republican-controlled House Oversight Committee’s actions show the mounting pressure for disclosure in a case that Trump has urged his supporters to move past. But they were also just the start of what can be a drawn out process.
articles.title: House committee demands Epstein files. Here's what could happen next

articles.description: President Donald Trump is bragging that Japan has given him, as part of a new trade framework, $550 billion to invest in the United States. It’s an astonishing figure, but still subject to negotiation and perhaps not the sure thing he’s portraying. He says 90% of any profits from the money invested would go to the U.S. even if Japan had put up the funds. He calls it “a signing bonus.” A key Japanese trade negotiator isn't discussing the terms. It's unclear the degree to which the $550 billion could represent new investment or flow into existing investment plans.
articles.title: Trump says Japan will invest $550 billion in US at his direction

articles.description: Gaza health officials and the ambulance service say at least 25 people were killed by Israeli airstrikes and gunshots overnight as ceasefire talks appear to have stalled and Palestinians in Gaza are facing famine. The majority of people were killed by gunfire waiting for aid trucks close to the Zikim crossing with Israel, officials said Saturday. The strikes come as ceasefire talks between Israel and Hamas have hit a standstill after the U.S and Israel recalled their negotiating teams this week throwing the future of the negotiations into further uncertainty. The United Nations and experts say that Palestinians in Gaza are at risk of famine, with reports of increasing numbers of people dying from causes related to malnutrition.
articles.title: At least 25 people killed by Israeli gunshots and strikes in Gaza, some while seeking aid

articles.description: Redistricting usually happens after the once-a-decade population count by the U.S. Census Bureau or in response to a court ruling. Now, Texas Republicans want to break that tradition. And other states could follow suit. President Trump has asked the Texas Legislature to create districts, in time for next year’s midterm elections, that will send five more Republicans to Washington and make it harder for Democrats to regain the majority and blunt his agenda. There's no national impediment to a state trying to redraw districts in the middle of a decade and to do it for political reasons, such as increasing representation by the party in power.
articles.title: How redistricting in Texas could reshape US House elections

articles.description: The National Weather Service has issued heat advisories for the southeastern United States. The advisories cover areas from central Florida to Virginia through the weekend. Temperatures are expected to reach the upper 90s, with heat indexes between 105 and 110. Extreme heat warnings are in effect for eastern North Carolina and parts of South Carolina. Forecasters warn of dangerously hot conditions, with temperatures approaching 100 degrees in parts of the Carolinas. Over 30 million people could be affected. The Midwest is also experiencing extreme heat, with watches in place for Nebraska, Iowa, and Minnesota. Storms in Iowa have triggered flash flood warnings.
articles.title: Heat advisories issued as temperatures soar in US Southeast

articles.description: Continuous glucose monitors that track the rise and fall of sugar in person's blood are growing in popularity. The quarter-size devices have been lifesaving for people with diabetes, but more people without the disease are using them. Experts say there is little evidence people with normal blood sugar levels need them. And they can't be used to diagnose or treat disease. Over-the-counter versions are available, but they can provide misleading or inaccurate data in people without diabetes.
articles.title: If you don't have diabetes, do you really need a continuous glucose monitor?

articles.description: Statehouses across the U.S. are addressing long-standing bathroom disparities for female lawmakers. In Kentucky, there is limited restroom access for women in the Statehouse, who risk missing debates or votes if they have to stand in line to answer the call of nature. A $300 million renovation, expected to be finished by at least 2028, will add more bathrooms for women. Similar efforts are underway in Georgia, reflecting a shift toward inclusivity. Historically, many statehouses were built without considering female legislators. Advocates say these changes symbolize a shift toward respect and equality, ensuring public spaces meet the needs of all lawmakers and the public.
articles.title: Female state lawmakers face bathroom stall shortage

articles.description: Beyoncé's daughter, Blue Ivy Carter, is captivating audiences on the Cowboy Carter tour. At just 13, she's impressing fans with her stage presence and growth since her first performance. The tour concludes Saturday in Las Vegas. Many fans, like Isabella Kerr, attend specifically to see Blue Ivy, who has been dubbed a "next generation powerhouse." Blue first performed at 11 during Beyoncé's Renaissance Tour. Her professionalism shines through in unexpected moments, like handling a wardrobe mishap calmly. Fans, calling themselves the "Ivy League," are inspired by her dedication and talent, seeing her as a role model for their own dreams.
articles.title: Blue Ivy shines on stage during Beyoncé's Cowboy Carter tour

articles.description: New York Yankees star Aaron Judge is out of the lineup against Philadelphia because of an elbow injury. Manager Aaron Boone said Saturday that Judge went for imaging. The two-time AL MVP was wincing in the outfield at Toronto this week. Boone says Judge struggled to throw a little bit in Friday night's loss to the Phillies. Boone wouldn’t speculate whether the injury involved Judge’s UCL.
articles.title: Aaron Judge out for Yankees' game vs. Phillies because of elbow injury
